setup.question: What best describes how the overall tone changed from the beginning of the article?

Text.text: Both seem plausible to me for a detective story.
its definitely upbeat in the beginning:
the story changes beat here:

- this is the center to the plot - Eddie's dad works as a scientist testing on uranium atoms in relation to nuclear power it seems. the special isoptope they are waiting on is stolen by someone who had knowledge about the shipment.
the story becomes sympathethic due to this robbery:

the story definitely does not end tense - the entire ending is a rather optimistic and neutral ending to a sad robbery.

Never get to the detective part. Story ends with a convo between main character, Eddie, and his friends Teena and her mom and dad. 

Story is about Eddie a big science nerd. His dad, atomic scientist at a college, has order of new radioisotope coming in. However, shipment stolen in middle of the story. The entire story is through the perspective of Eddie

Although the ending is a convo so kinda chill, the two ask Eddie to explain radioisotope, and talk about the danger of the stolen radioisotope:

I think Debater A might have forgotten to say something about the robbery?

Points in favor of B:
- The Q asks how the tone changes from the beginning, so the main turn in the story (where the radioisotope is stolen) seems more relevant than the end.
- Both debaters seem to agree that the story is tense in the middle.
- Debater B has further evidence of tension late in the story.

Could the debaters please provide a more complete description of the relevant parts of the plot, and what the characters are feeling  with evidence  instead of relying just on the tone of some select sentences?

And Debater A, can you explain in what way the story is "sympathetic" at the end?

yes - the story is sympathethic over tense because everyone feels really bad for Eddie's dad and Teena's dad. there's a lot of ev for this that i couldn't get to last speech due to limits.
also im unsure what you mean, "forgot" - i mentioned it in my speech?
1.

- this was B's quote but proves Mrs. Ross (mother of Eddie's BFF Teena) understands
2.

- same character, more sympathy
3.

- afformentioned best friend of Eddie's
4.
- literally the last line of the story. story is not tense, nukes stuff mentioned once.
There is a reason why the tone is tense but not dramatic. The whole town is on edge about things to come towards the end of the story, especially our main character Eddie:

More ev to come about other characters being "on edge." and I can give more ev on the middle portion when Eddie's father tells him about the stolen shipment. 

Unfortunately Eddie doesn't actually witness the robbery; further ev why the tone is tense and not dramatic.

I'm feeling a bit confused. It seems like the upbeat/lighthearted distinction isn't relevant so this comes down to sympathetic versus tense. It seems like there is both tension and sympathy near the end. But which qualifies as the "overall tone"? I can't say. I need the debaters to actually describe to me what's going on in the story and explain the quotes to me, or tell me how to weigh the competing evidence here. It seems to me like saying which qualifies as the "overall tone" should require determining which conversations are most relevant to the story and representative of what is happening in it more broadly. What is the situation at the end? Has the tension resolved? Why are they conversing like this if there's a thief on the loose?

B is just straight up lying - "the whole town is on edge"? what. we only meet like 4 characters and half of them literally don't understand the nuke/atomic stuff. Teena's mother and Teena are literally completely clueless:

. They sort of get it, sure, but its clearly not a question of "we are all going to die tension" but rather "well that sucks, hoping it works out for your father" type sympathy.

Situation at end: no, nothing is resolved. Story ends with Eddie talking to a sad Teena's father - this is unrelated to the isotope stuff.
sure 'whole town on edge' is a bit of speculation on my part but clear that its the main news/drama in town. stolen shipment was posted the day of on local news:

clear that local residents are concerned about it given the response. furthermore, try read A's ev on characters asking what radioisotopes are as them trying to ease their tension/concern. they don't know what the potential dangers are and that typically results in tension of the unknown. 

times 'danger' is cited in last convo is telling:

Omg. People. I asked for CONTEXT on what is happening more BROADLY in the story. And I need REASONS to WEIGH your evidence against each other's in the context of the question of the story's OVERALL TONE. Clearly there is tension and there is sympathy. Both of those things have been established. BUT HOW DO I ANSWER THE QUESTION??? I got a TINY bit of that this round but don't waste our time quoting the word "dangerous" a bajillion times.

context - this isn't a complex story. eddie's dad's isotope is stolen, and he spends the rest of the story hanging with Teena, explaining to her what went wrong. thats all that happens
Yeah you can weigh sympathy over tension because all those 'dangerous' comes from the conversation where Eddie is trying to explain to his best friend Teena and her mom, and they honestly only kind of get it. that and eddie talking to his dad.

story ends sympathethic:
7467-7478 comes here (already quoted check it)

understood boss will not cite a single word this round. like A said, what happens in the story is pretty straightforward: Eddie super excited for the day, comes back finds out shipment was stolen, that's all he wants to think about (have ev for this but i made a promise), chats with dad to learn about where + how possibly it was stolen, chats with friends. 

now let's just think about this story from a storytelling perspective. given the title its a spy thriller (damn broke my promise)
what makes the most sense is to set up tension now so eddie can solve the mystery later on. Sympathetic is more suited for the ending of a story not the rising action.

Debater B's sass is giving sussy fr bruh skull emoji. Also B is consistently appealing to "what would make the most sense" for the tone to be whereas A is talking about what is actually happening in the story. Then again, A isn't saying all that much.

A, can you elaborate on the "hoping it works out for your father" point? Are they sympathetic to the father? What might or might not work out for him? And what are they worried about?

B, can you illustrate the reasons for the tension? The idea that spies stole it is a good example. What are the stakes? How is Eddie feeling at the end? Can you explain the latest quote A gave in the story where Eddie is thinking everyone has problems? What's that about & does it relate to the tension?
Yeah the story ends with Teena's mom and Teena being nice to Mr. Ross (Teena's dad) who is depressed. seems like he works on a plant but its not explained:
Check the quotes tab now cuz i alr quoted the last few lines that immediately follow this.

(quoting that too cuz i left it out from a prev speech cuz limits). the quote tab should really clear up the whole picture. I wanna reiterate - we have no idea what Mr. Ross is sad about - this is his only place to the story, but it clearly flows A.

Stakes are very high, he makes it clear to Teena and mom but is most telling in the conversation he has with his father after it is stolen. The father states the shipment is top-secret and dangerousraising the stakes.
His father is also convinced that it spies from another country talking about how the operation was:
and guessed that it was sent to
Also stating people

emphasis on mighty. 

A quotes can be read as tense as well. Symp is limited to Teena and mom at best, both dads are tense.

Thanks folks. I'm still pretty uncertain. Can both of you try and refute the other's position? A, are you saying the story isn't tense, and can you refute B's argument for why it is? and B, are you saying the story's tone isn't sympathetic, and can you refute A's argument about the story more broadly beyond what you've already said about the quotes at the end?

It would also be really helpful if, with any remaining evidence budget you have, you could work on quoting a full representative paragraph which conveys the tone of the story. It's really hard for me to assess things just based on these smaller quotes. Thanks.

Refuting B:
1. The nukes stress happens middle of the story characters 3000-4000 (check B's ev), story ends in the 7000s - its not a tense ending
2. Teena's mother and Teena barely get it:
3. Eddie's father doesn't even necessarily think that its a nuclear bomb level disaster - he just is worried about a part of his life's work being lost.

- i mean this is the middle of when the story most seems a little "tense" and there's still jokes and humor. 
4. B can't answer my arg about the story's end

1 and 4. dk why emphasizing tense ending... oh wait cuz the only place with a hint of symp is the very last convo. But question asks how the tone changes THROUGHOUT not just the ending. Just ask A to cite ev for sympathy in other places. 
2. 6756
3. what. just worried about a part of his life's work lost? and that quote is somehow supposed to support that? alr have ev for how dangerous dad thinks it could be. just ask A to cite ev of sympathy here. 

Judge focus beyond just the ending, look at mood not convo:

Bro B that last quote is clutch, I wish you brought it out earlier. This is the first time you actually showed me a character being anxious. I asked at the beginning for "what the characters are feeling  with evidence" and finally we are seeing the sweet fruit. And A shows me Eddie is exasperated as well.

Alright I'll give more chances. Both debaters, please show me how characters are feeling!! The dialogue alone without context isn't enough, because it could be delivered in so many ways with so many contexts. But the text mentioning their anxiety or exasperation is a strong clue!

debater B is just using a quote that seems 'tense' without any context.
1. this is eddie's childlike thinking - he is assuming the worst. This also isn't how the story ends which I think both you and debater B are kind of missing.
2. this isn't even that tense lol because the story doesn't elaborate or explain who stole the materials conclusively

when Eddie's dad is guilty is sad:

"Then Eddie heard the sound of his father's voice coming from the den.

The door to the den was open" (3027-3058)

"His father sat stiffly behind his homemade desk, talking rapidly into the telephone" (3071-3087)
